June 26, 1968
ETV REPORTER
Page 5
A NUMBER OF THE NATION’S TOP INDUSTRIALISTS WILL BE INTERVIEWED IN A NEW
series, "Faces of Business—USA,77 being produced by WNDT (Ch. 13) New York. Appear¬
ing in the series of six color programs will be Henry Ford II, Chairman of the Board of Ford
Motor Co.; John J. Johnson, President of Johnson Publishing Co.; James J. Ling, Chairman
and Chief Executive Officer of Ling-Temco-V ought, Inc.; Charles F. Luce, Chairman of the
Board of Con Edison; David Rockefeller, President and Chairman of the Executive Committee
of Chase Manhattan Bank; and Joseph C. Wilson Chairman of the Board of Xerox Corp.
Each program will consist of a 30-minute interview conducted by T. A. Wide, a member of the
Fortune magazine board of editors. The series will premiere July 9 at 7:30 P. M. with an ap¬
pearance by Xerox Corp. 's Wilson. Betsy Pilat Marston will produce the series, which was
made possible by a public service grant from the George F. Baker trust.
NEW ETV LITERATURE AVAILABLE FROM —
RSA Information Service, Social and Rehabilitation Service, U. S. Dept, of Health, Edu-
cation and Welfare, Washington, D. C. 20201. A new catalog of films on mental retardation,
which lists both professional and non-professional films dealing with the nature of mental re¬
tardation, its causes, general treatment and prevention, is available free on request. Other
films listed describe the more specific aspects of diagnosis, clinical treatment, rehabilitation
and control.
AmpexCorp.', 401 Broadway, Redwood City, Calif. 94063. A new 16-page brochure
describes the firm’s capabilities for designing, engineering, and installing complete televi¬
sion systems, including broadcast TV stations, remote units, closed circuit systems, and
other audio and video systems for broadcast, military, educational, medical, business and
industrial applications.
A GROUP OF PUSHING, SHOVING "HIPPIES, " SHOUTING OBSCENITIES, INVADED THE
studios of WNDT (Ch. 13) New York Tuesday night while the station was on the air and
took over the facilities before being subdued by police. The intruders, numbering about
20, including several women, knocked down a guard and punched their way past two mem¬
bers of the station’s staff. Six men and one woman were arrested but the rest escaped.
The entire incident, including the shouting of a number of four-letter words, went out
over the air. Staff members said they were afraid the intruders might wreck the sta¬
tion if they were cut off the air. Former Astronaut John Glenn, who had appeared on
a program preceding the one disrupted by the hippies, looked on in astonishment during
the incident. Station officials said they will charge the arrested individuals with crimi¬
nal trespass.
WET A (CH. 26) WASHINGTON IS ASSISTING THE TEACHER ORIENTATION PROGRAM
of Project Head Start in the District of Columbia and parts of Maryland. This week the
station is airing five 20-minute Head Start films at 3:40 P.M. Head Start is directed at
pre-school children whose background and experience place them at a disadvantage as they
begin formal schooling, and provides these children with intensive training during the sum¬
mer months designed to reduce that disadvantage.
THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT HAS ORDERED 50 MARK 10 VIDEO PROCESSING AND
automatic gain control amplifiers from Ball Brothers Research Corp., Boulder, Colo.,
for processing of video pickups from the Summer Olympic Games. Delivery will be at
the rate of 10 units in June, 10 in July and the final 30 in August. They will be instal¬
led at several locations in Mexico in time for the beginning of the games in October.
